The measure now heads to the House
column2: and then finally to President Donald Trump for his signature. Only two Republicans -- Sens. Rand Paul of Kentucky and Mike Lee of Utah -- joined with 16 Democrats to vote no against the bill. Arizona Sen. John McCain was not present for the vote as he is back in his home state receiving treatment for brain cancer. The vote was held three days after the government officially shut down Friday at midnight. Here is how every senator voted:  Alabama Sen. Doug Jones

column1: 2017-04-25	https://www.cnn.com/2017/04/25/opinions/confederate-monuments-new-orleans-bailey-opinion/index.html	How to reckon with a Confederate past 	12	1	Virginia	" (CNN) Confederate monuments and Confederate flags on public property weren't designed to honor the leaders of the Confederate States of America. That's  what's changing in New Orleans  as construction workers undertake the work of removing four statues and monuments dedicated to one of the worst periods of US history. It harkens back to the days white violence was used to oppress black Southerners
column2: especially when they dared to make progress at the ballot box
column3: in the classroom
column4: to assert their God-given rights. Corey Stewart
column5: a Republican hoping to be the next governor of Virginia
column6: and others like him are so blinded by their rage
column7: their hatred
column8: they can't see the irony in their protests. The Confederate leaders Stewart and others want to forever have places of honor gave rise to a Jim Crow South where systematic lynching
column9: raping
column10: and killing occurred on our soil for longer and caused more damage than ISIS has in the Middle East. Leaving up Confederate flag and monuments built by men honoring that horror would be akin to forcing the victims of ISIS to forever live under the notorious ISIS black flag and live amid monuments and statutes dedicated to ""brave"" ISIS commanders. Removing those statues
column11: like renaming buildings that bear their name or taking down the Confederate flag -- and even reexamining the presence of slave owners and slave rapists on our currency -- is a long overdue reckoning with our past. Museums are designed to contend with the complexity of these men's legacies
column12: something that can't be practically done with a few lines of text carved into a statue. We are well into the 21st century and have yet to find the moral courage to say that if you commit some of the most horrific acts known to man -- owning other human beings
column13: betraying your country to preserve slavery -- you forfeit the right to be remembered on public monuments and statues and currency that should be reserved for only the best among us."	16	6

column1: 2010-08-08	http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/08/06/virginia-official-calls-congress-subpoena-ice-records.html	ICE Agrees to Release Illegal Immigrant Data to Virginia Official	12	2	Virginia	" ADVERTISEMENT Corey Stewart
column2: chairman of the   County
column3: Va.
column4: board of supervisors
column5: wanted information from ICE officials to find out how many criminal illegal immigrants referred for deportation are released back into the communities where they were picked up. They have agreed to release to Prince William County the identities and final disposition of every convicted criminal illegal alien apprehended in Prince William County
column6: Virginia and turned over to ICE through the county's 287(g) partnership
column7: Stewart said in a statement. But immigration officials released Montano
column8: who allegedly killed Sister Denise Mosier and injured two other nuns in the Aug. 1 accident
column9: on his own recognizance pending a deportation hearing. ""I want the Obama administration to come clean with the American people about its policy of releasing illegal aliens who localities and other law enforcement officials have identified as illegal aliens who have committed crimes
column10: and the Obama administration is simply turning around and releasing these dangerous individuals back into neighborhoods
column11: Stewart said. Stewart said he'd like to see Congress and the president fund facilities to hold illegal immigrants suspected of other crimes in jails throughout their trial phase
column12: and if found guilty

column6: ""Dreams"":   Hold fast to dreams For if dreams die Life is a broken-winged bird That cannot fly. Since Hughes' poem makes no allusion to politics or racism

column8: no matter how privileged
column9: is exempt. Nevertheless
column10: it is difficult to know that a young black man composed it during some of the worst years of Jim Crow in America and not see it at once as a political rallying cry despite its sentimentality. Martin Luther King Jr. would pick up on Hughes' dream imagery in his most celebrated oration
column11: which we remember for its recurrent assertion ""I Have a Dream."" One is reminded also of Hughes' militant anthem of the Great Depression
column12: ""Let America Be America Again

column14: and yet America ""must be."") Introducing Clinton
column15: Kaine paired the sentimentality of Hughes with something much more muscular
column16: and even menacing. It's a strange turnaround
column17: and an odd application of the deeper lessons of the Civil War

column19: like Bull Run

column23: a new civil war

Copley became a household name in the 2016 presidential campaign when he confronted then-Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton about her stance on coal after hearing her say in a CNN Town Hall the month before: “We’re going to put a lot of coal miners and coal companies out of business.” Clinton later apologized to Copley and told him she misspoke. But seeing Manchin beside Clinton at the Williamson Town Hall — where hundreds of protesters lined the street — “didn’t sit right” with Copley. He said Manchin’s “unwavering support” of the former Secretary of State was enough to motivate him to run for office. Copley said he showed Clinton a picture of his children that day to represent the future of a now-dying coal industry in the Mountain State. “How can you make comments about taking jobs away from people and look at the children of those people in the face and still be able to make those kind of comments?” he reflected.
